Ruth Ben-Ghiat is Chair of the Department of Italian Studies and Professor of Italian Studies and History in the Faculty of Arts and Science. She is a specialist in the cinema and culture of Italy, with fields of research in Italian colonialism and postcolonialism, empire cinema, Fascism, cinema and war, and neorealism. She is the author of Fascist Modernities: Italy 1922-45 (Berkeley, 2001, 2004), and the editor of Gli imperi: dall’antichità all’età contemporanea (Mulino, 2009), and (with Mia Fuller) of Italian Colonialism (New York, 2005, 2008). Her latest articles are “Un cinéma d’après-guerre: le néoréalisme italien et la transition democratique,” Annales. Histoires, Sciences Sociales (novembre-décembre 2008), and “Italian Fascism’s empire cinema: the conquest of Libya and the assault on the nomadic,” in Postcolonial Cinema Studies , eds. Sandra Ponzanesi and Marguerite Waller (New York, 2011). Her latest book, Fascism’s Empire Cinema: Histories and Journeys of Italian Conquest and Defeat , will be published by Indiana University Press. International Cinema: Origins to 1960: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Undergraduate Film & Television Admissions About the Program Course Offerings Summer Courses Showcase Internships Facilities Special Projects First Run & Festivals Calendar of Events News TSOA FTV Wiki Admin & Faculty Alumni Blog Facebook Twitter YouTube  home > Undergraduate Film & TV        International Cinema: Origins to 1960  FMTV-UT.321 Lecture 4 Credits  Offered in the Fall semester only.  Course Level: Intermediate No prerequisite    This course provides a broad overview of world cinema from its origins until the emergence of modern cinema in the 1960's. It addresses numerous national cinemas (French, German, Italian, Japanese, Scandinavian, Soviet, British, Indian) and examines both how representative films from each country emerges out of its national culture and also negotiates with the dominant aesthetic of Hollywood film. The approach will be stylistic, including the development of narrative, various cinematic modernisms, and technological advances such as the introduction of sound; industrial, including the formation of the studio system and the creation of national film cultures in response; and social, including propaganda and political (leftist) films and documentaries. Whenever possible, this course emphasizes the cross-pollination of film styles across national cultures such as the mutual influence of 1920's avant-garde movements, the concentration of political filmmaking in the 1930's, or the influence of neorealism on post-war cinema. Some films to be screened: Strike, L'age d'or, M, Housing Problems, Umberto D, Tokyo Story , and Pather Panchali. Study Abroad Summer High School Summer in New York City Programs for Visiting Students Open Arts Minors Blog Events Newsletters Videos Admin & Faculty Alumni Contact Us  home > Special Programs        Writing in Florence   Program Overview Florence was home to Dante, Boccaccio, Michelangelo, and Botticelli and   remains a city with a vibrant cultural life. Students will have the   opportunity to draw on these artistic wellsprings, while benefiting from   the peace and inspiration offered by NYU’s Villa La Pietra, surrounded   by 57 acres of gardens and olive groves, where they will live and work. Students enroll in both courses for a total of 8 units. These courses are   designed to complement each other, enabling students to be inspired and   integrate knowledge and firsthand experience of Florence in their   writing. Program Curriculum Students must take the following two courses for a total of 8 units.  Developing the Dramatic Script for Film or Theatre IDWPG-UT 1410.001 4 units Instructor: Len Jenkin In this script development tutorial and writing retreat students will develop, write and revise a full-length stage play or feature-length screenplay through a series of lectures and one-on-one consultations with the instructor, rigorous writing exercises, and sustained writing time. The course focuses on the basic techniques of dramatic writing, including developing the dramatic idea, characterization, plot, dialogue, them and the revision process in film and theatre. The class includes lectures, discussion, analysis, writing exercises, workshop and individual conferences. The summer session culminates in table readings at La Pietra of scenes from the completed work. Additionally, students will be offered a series of retreat experiences. These experiences might include a day of silence; a day of total absorption in a painting, a building, a sculpture; working with drawing and music. While the exercises will vary, the purpose of each will be the same-- to unlock and engage the student’s natural creativity. Students will complete a first draft of a script by the end of the session. Emphasis will be on honing the creative process to enable students to think critically and creatively about a work in progress, incorporating feedback, and completing a project in a limited time frame. Introduction to Italian Cinema ICINE-UT 1103.001 4 units Instructor: Vito Zagarrio The  course is an historical overview of the Italian Film, from the origins up to  today, through the debate on some crucial moments. There is a large re-vision  of Italian Cinema, concerning some Italian history periods which are being  re-discussed, such as the Fascist era and the so called Boom (the economic  growth). The scholars are changing some judgments and the spectators are  changing their taste. As matter of fact, the course will analyze some “crossing  points” of the Italian film history and investigate the major debates on some crucial  moments of Italian society.   The  Italian Cinema is a good way to study the whole Italian history, society,  ideology and behaviours. The students will have the opportunity to know such  authors as Rossellini, De Sica, Fellini, Antonioni, Visconti, Pasolini, and Bertolucci,  who are well known even in the US. They will deal with the national mode of  production, the notion of “auteur film”.   The main  historical periods are the following: the shift between Fascism and the  Post-war period, the so called “Neorealism”, the economic growth, the sixties  and seventies, and the contemporary time. Main areas of interest will be film  history, the relationship between cinema and the social-political context, and  the different theoretical approaches to film.
